subject: Technology
title: Location Tracking: Your Phone Knows Where You Are
description: A micro-lesson that makes Location Tracking: Your Phone Knows Where You Are usable.

hook.text: Your phone logs your location every few minutes. Companies use that data to know where you eat, sleep, work, and worship.

buildup.text: Apps request location access for legitimate features like maps. But many sell that data to advertisers and data brokers.

discovery.text: A New York Times investigation tracked a single phone and identified the person, their home, office, and daily routine.

twist.text: Even with location services off, your phone can be tracked through Wi-Fi signals, cell towers, and Bluetooth beacons.

climax.text: Location data has been used to track protesters, identify affair partners, and target vulnerable people.

punchline.text: Your phone always knows where you are. So does everyone who buys that data.

quiz.question: Can your phone be tracked with location services turned off?
options: No, turning off location completely prevents tracking
Yes, through Wi-Fi signals, cell towers, and Bluetooth beacons
Only if you're making a phone call
